items.title: U.S. government admits negligence in January helicopter-plane collision near Washington
items.summary_auto: The U.S. government admitted Wednesday that the Federal Aviation Administration and the Army played a role in causing the collision last January between an airliner and a Black Hawk helicopter near the nation's capital, killing 67 people.

items.title: Canada's 2030 climate target far out of reach, according to Environment Canada data
items.summary_auto: Canada's legally binding climate target seems to be out of reach, according to new data released from Environment and Climate Change Canada.

items.title: Are floor-crossers traitors? | About That
items.summary_auto: Conservative Ontario MP Michael Ma crossed the floor to join the Liberals just weeks after another Conservative MP made the same move, leaving Prime Minister Mark Carney's Liberal government one seat shy of a majority. Andrew Chang breaks down how floor-crossing works and why, although it may appear to contradict democracy — it's not breaking any rules. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: FBI deputy chief Dan Bongino to leave post in January
items.summary_auto: FBI Deputy Director Dan Bongino will step down from his post next month, he said on Wednesday, ending a short and at times tumultuous tenure as the bureau's second highest-ranking official.

items.title: RCMP not aware of fentanyl in illegal cannabis in Nova Scotia, despite premier's claims
items.summary_auto: The Nova Scotia RCMP says it's not aware of any fentanyl-laced cannabis being sold by unauthorized cannabis retailers in the province, after the premier made this claim in a news conference last week. The claim raises tensions with Mi'kmaw communities amid a province-wide crackdown aimed largely at on-reserve cannabis dispensaries.

items.title: 2nd child hit by school bus in less than a month has Laval, Que., parents calling for changes
items.summary_auto: A seven-year-old girl is expected to survive after being hit by a Laval, Que., school bus only four weeks after a 13-year-old girl died following a similar incident in the Montreal suburb.

items.title: Carney says 'spectrum of MPs' attracted to his party, dismisses claim he's manipulating a majority
Snow fun allowed? Winter play guidelines for some Quebec schools spark backlash
items.summary_auto: Some Quebec schools are being encouraged to follow a long list of rules for playing on snow mounds, including the possibility of forcing kids to wear helmets, sparking yet another debate about whether child safety fears have gone too far.

items.title: Inside the 1st stop of the PWHL’s Takeover Tour, as the league eyes further expansion
items.summary_auto: Tickets sold out quickly for two PWHL games in Halifax, which hopes to be the next city to secure a PWHL team. The league is looking at expanding by as many as four additional teams as soon as next season.

items.title: Running in Antarctica — backward? Why not, these racers say
items.summary_auto: Ice, ice, baby! A group of marathon runners awaiting a flight out of Antarctica staged a backward mile run on Dec. 15. While some competitors slipped and stumbled on their way to the finish line, the eventual victor hailing from Montreal called the sub-zero conditions 'perfect.'

items.title: Trump to deliver primetime address as polls suggest some voters are souring on his presidency
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump will deliver a primetime address to the country Wednesday evening as polls suggest his popularity has slumped in recent weeks as persistent cost-of-living challenges turn some voters off his presidency.

items.title: Canada’s strong Olympic short track speed skating team for Milano Cortina unveiled
items.summary_auto: Canada’s short track speed skating team for the Milano Cortina Olympic Games was announced on Wednesday, and the 10-athlete roster will be led by William Dandjinou and Courtney Sarault, the respective men’s and women’s Crystal Globe winners at this year’s World Tour.

items.title: Man accused of severing essential undersea telecom cable between Nova Scotia, Newfoundland
items.summary_auto: Wrapped in coils of thick wire, the cable was a primary connection for internet, TV and long-distance communication between the two provinces.

items.title: Carney, Ford to sign a deal to reduce regulatory burden on Ring of Fire, speed up Ontario projects
items.summary_auto: Ottawa and Ontario are set to sign a deal Thursday that will reduce the regulatory burden on large projects, including the road to the Ring of Fire.

items.title: U.S. fugitive ‘psychic’ in Toronto won’t fight extradition over deadly 1998 Christmas Day crash
items.summary_auto: Twenty-seven years after a deadly Christmas Day crash in Florida, a longtime fugitive in Toronto has signalled he will not fight extradition to face manslaughter charges. A CBC News investigation this year revealed Patrick Lutts Jr. lived openly in the city, working as a self-styled psychic.

items.title: Oscars ceremony will be streamed on YouTube exclusively starting in 2029
items.summary_auto: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has inked a deal with YouTube that will give the video-streaming platform exclusive rights to broadcast the Oscars beginning in 2029, until 2033.

items.title: Nick Reiner appears in court on murder charges in his parents' deaths
items.summary_auto: Nick Reiner is charged with two counts of first-degree murder in the killing of his parents. He appeared from behind the glass wall of a custody area wearing shackles and a suicide prevention smock, and spoke only a handful of words.

items.title: Eli Wood's mom is 'imploring you to please help' find the Kitchener, Ont., 25-year-old as reward offered
items.summary_auto: Eli Wood, 25, went missing on Oct. 19 after a fire at his Kitchener, Ont., home. Police say foul play is suspected in the disappearance of the Wilfrid Laurier University student. Now, his family is offering a $5,000 reward for information about his whereabouts.

items.title: ‘Safe travel impossible’ on southern Alberta roads as winter storm hits Prairies, officials warn
Quebec Liberal leader steps down after weeks of turmoil: sources
Alberta shuts down supervised drug consumption site in Edmonton hospital
items.summary_auto:
Alberta has closed one of three supervised consumption sites in Edmonton, continuing the push to shutter such locations as the
province moves away from overdose prevention to focus on recovery and treatment.

items.title: Storm knocks out power for thousands across B.C.
Warner Bros. asks investors to reject takeover bid from Paramount Skydance
items.summary_auto: Warner Bros. is telling shareholders to reject a takeover bid from Paramount Skydance, saying that a rival bid from Netflix will be better for customers.

items.title: Health experts urge parents not to buy kids e-scooters for Christmas
items.summary_auto: Citing injury risk and little-known laws around private e-scooter usage, emergency department physician Dr. Stephanie VandenBerg says she gives an “unequivocal nay” to gifting e-scooters for Christmas.

items.title: U.S. ski towns hope holiday season marks turnaround after slump in Canadian visitors
Olivia and Noah are most popular baby names in Ontario. Muhammad cracks top 10
items.summary_auto: Olivia and Noah are once again the most popular names for new babies in Ontario, according to a list released by the province on Tuesday. And Muhammad appears for the first time in at least 10 years on the list.

items.title: Rare instance of polar bear cub being adopted near Churchill verified by scientists
items.summary_auto: Scientists were recently greeted with a most unexpected surprise when a polar bear mother and her cub were walking near Churchill in mid-November when scientists witnessed the mother adopt a second cub, marking just the 13th such case of cub adoption within the western Hudson Bay study population of northeastern Manitoba.

items.title: Under pressure to surrender land to Russia, Zelenskyy pitches a referendum
Undocumented children fear being stuck in state of limbo that could last years
items.summary_auto: Undocumented youth in Canada say they’re feeling worried and hopeless as they face decades-long processing times for permanent residence under the humanitarian and compassionate pathway. Lawyers fear more children will lose their status in the coming years, forcing them to go underground.

items.title: Bare trust tax filings on pause again as government mulls exemptions
items.summary_auto: Canada's tax agency says it doesn't expect Canadians who hold simple trusts, known as bare trusts, to file required tax forms this coming tax season — but legislative changes currently before the House of Commons means the requirements will likely be there in 2027.

items.title: How ISIS could be linked to the deadly Bondi Beach mass shooting
items.summary_auto: The suspects alleged to have carried out the deadly mass shooting at Sydney's Bondi Beach may have been inspired by ISIS or provided actual training to help carry out the attack, experts of the militant group say.
